about.label: About
about.paragraphOne: MeadTools came to me as an idea to help my mead making community      while simultaneously kickstarting a new career in software      development. There are several other tools to assist in mead making,      but most are confusing to beginners, or, in my opinion incomplete.      My hope is that MeadTools solves these issues.
about.paragraphThree: MeadTools is completely open source under a MIT license, so if you      want to check out the code, please have a look over on GitHub. If      you use any of the code for anything fun, I just ask that you share      it with me and the rest of the mead making community.
about.paragraphTwo: Below I have listed all of the resources that I used in the creation      of MeadTools as well as additional mead making resources. I can’t      thank my personal mead community enough for making this project      possible. I can be found on discord in the Doin’ the Most and Man      Made Mead Mazer servers. My user name is larry_r. There is also a      brand new MeadTools discord. I can be contacted through the contact      page, linked on the bottom bar directly at contact@meadtools.com.

thanks.text: To the entire mead making community, for all of the help, inspiration, and knowledge I have gained over the past 4 years

desktop.dataConfirm: This action cannot be undone. This will reset your data back to default values.
desktop.dialogDescription: This action will not remove the files from your computer, it simply removes the path from your local database.

charts.body:
Upload your Tilt, Rapt Pill, or iSpindel data. Create your own
              charts with manually entered hydrometer data.
charts.label: Recipe Charting

customization.body:
All ingredients and yeasts can be modified or added to. This
              allows you to have a truly customized experience.
customization.label: Ingredient Customization

offline.body:
MeadTools desktop requires no online capability. All data is
              stored locally. It also allows you to save recipes locally as .mead files.
offline.label: Offline capability

desktop.ingredientWarning: This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete this ingredient.
desktop.yeastDelete: This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete this yeast.

dialog.content:
Hey there, fellow mead enthusiasts! I’m Larry, the creator of MeadTools, your all-in-one mead calculator designed to simplify the brewing process. 

Whether you’re calculating yeast nutrients, alcohol content, or other odds and ends, MeadTools has you covered! If you’ve found value in using MeadTools and would like to help support its continued development, consider making a donation through Ko-fi.

Every contribution goes directly towards improving the app with new features, better tools, and ensuring it stays free for everyone. Your support helps keep this community-driven project thriving, and together we can make mead-making easier and more accessible for all! 

Thank you for being a part of this journey. Cheers to your next brew! 🍻
dialog.title: Support MeadTools on Ko-fi! 🍯🍷

The above token is used along with the iSpindel Name to identify your
        devices and link them to your account. Please make sure that you have a
        different iSpindel Name for each of your devices to avoid overlap when
        logging data. If you regenerate your token you will need to update it on ALL of your devices for your logs to be saved.

tipText.abvSeriousWarning: Producing an ABV above 23% by fermentation alone is not possible.
tipText.abvWarning: Producing an ABV above 20% is highly unlikely by fermentation alone without step feeding.
tipText.additives: Any ingredient that doesn't provide fermentable sugars is best placed here. You can use one of the suggested ingredients or add your own.
tipText.adjustYanValue: This field should only be edited by users who want precise control over their YAN ratios. It is strongly recommended that it only be edited by experienced Mead Makers.

benchTrials.body: Bench Trials are a complicated topic that require further research than I can easily provide here. Follow these links for additional information

tipText.brix: Brix measures the amount of dissolved solids in solution. 1g of sucrose in 100ml of water is 1 Brix, so it is roughly the same as percent sugar. You can measure brix with a refractometer, calculate it by nutrition facts, or convert your SG to brix over on ExtraCalc to use custom sugar percentages in this calculator.
tipText.campden: Campden tablets vary quite a bit in the amount of free SO2 that they provide MeadTools assumes that one campden tablet provides 75PPM of free SO2.
tipText.delleUnits: Delle units are a measure of microbial stability. The higher the number, the more likely the brew is stable without the need for additional additives or stabilization methods. Delle units are calculated based on the amount of residual sugar and the ABV of the brew. 73 delle units is considered stable by most, but the actual number varies. Alcohol tolerance is NOT considered in delle stability. Read more
tipText.desiredDetailsForm: This form is for getting an initial must with your desired Original Gravity and volume. Using this form after you have entered other ingredients WILL CLEAR out all ingredients beyond one honey row and one water row.
tipText.estimatedFg: Unless you are planning for this mead to stop early, it is best to leave this field at .996, this estimate will be close enough for most recipes.
tipText.goFerm: Type of Go-ferm effects the amount of water needed for rehydration and the effectiveness of the Fermaid O.
tipText.maxGpl: These numbers are calculated based on the nutrient schedule you pick. They are editable if you choose, but that is not recommended unless you know what you're doing.
tipText.nitrogenRequirements: Determined by your yeast strain. If your yeast is not on the list, and you do not know its nitrogen requirement, enter it as Other: Other Medium N Yeast. This field is also editable if you want to use a yeast at a different requirement level than typical.
tipText.numberOfAdditions: Staggered nutrient additions are useful in preventing temperature spikes during fermentation that can stress the yeast. Four nutrient additions is probably the most common regimen, but I personally use three additions or a single addition in most cases.
tipText.nutrientSg: This is the difference in gravity, taking FG into account. For example, if your OG is listed as 1.100 and your FG is 1.010, this field will read 1.090. This can field can be edited.
tipText.offsetPpm: Some musts contain some YAN by themselves. This calculator automatically assumes 25ppm per pound of fruit per gallon, but if you would like to change the offset the field is editable.
tipText.ogSeriousWarning: This brew will likely finish fermenting above 1.000 even with step feeding and proper nutrition. If your OG is above 1.170, fermentation may trouble starting.
tipText.ogWarning: Consider step feeding honey at this gravity.
tipText.oneThird: When 1/3 of the sugars in the must have been consumed. This number is often used for the timing of the final nutrient addition.
tipText.preferredSchedule: This calculator allows you to enter any combination of Fermaid O, K, and DAP. It is really up to you which nutrients or combinations you decide to use, but certain combos are better for certain situations. Read more about nutrients and schedules
tipText.remainingYan: If your remaining YAN is more than 0, you should consider adjusting the max g/L field. Keep in mind you should probably keep your amount of DAP under .96g/L for risk of off-flavors. Also the TTB limit on Fermaid K is .5g/L due to the limit on thiamine. This is not a concern for homebrewers.
tipText.stabilizers: Potassium sorbate (k-sorb) AND potassium metabisulfite (k-meta) are both needed to prevent refermentation. They cannot be reliably used to STOP fermentation in most cases. Amounts of k-meta needed for stabilizing are based on your pH. MeadTools assumes 50ppm if you choose not to take a pH reading. K-sorb amount is based on your ABV. It is not effective above around 16%. More info can be found
tipText.totalSecondary: This is the estimated volume of the entire batch including secondary fermentables. This calculator assumes that anything you listed above as a secondary ingredient will not be fermented on.
tipText.totalVolume: This total volume is an estimate of only the fermentables in solution during primary fermentation, your actual volume WILL be higher if using high fruit loads.
tipText.volumeLines: The first two lines only contain liquid ingredients, all lines on this calculator can be added by either volume or weight.
tipText.yan: Yeast Assimilable Nitrogen (YAN) is the amount of nitrogen needed by your yeast to have a healthy fermentation. Your target YAN is determined by your initial gravity and your yeast's nitrogen requirements.
tipText.yeastAmount: The yeast amount in this calculator is based on the gravity reading and total volume. The amount is editable, and I recommend that you round up to the nearest packet in most cases.

tiptext.refractometerWarning: This value should only be adjusted if you have spent time calculating the correction factor for your specific refractometer. More info can be found

cardFive.step1: This page allows you to add additional additives that don't provide sugar to your brew.
cardFive.step2: The input on the left will allow you to search for additives from the MeadTools list and get suggested amounts based on your volume or input your own custom ones.
cardFive.step3: Important note: the searchable additives only give suggestions in one unit. If you'd like to add them in a different unit, you can, but MeadTools will not adjust them for you.

cardFour.step1: This page shows you the amount of stabilizers needed for your brew. You can adjust the pH reading if you'd like to dial in your sorbate amounts.

cardOne.step1: Welcome to the Recipe Builder! Let us show you around.
cardOne.step10: Press this button to fill this ingredient to the next gallon or liter.
cardOne.step11: These are your recipe calculator results. It shows you things like your volume, OG, and ABV. Check the tooltips for more information about individual fields.
cardOne.step12: The final thing for this page is the scale recipe form. This will scale all your ingredients to whatever batch size you input. Let's move on to the nutrient calculator now.
cardOne.step2: This sidebar allows you to navigate through the different recipe builder steps with ease.
cardOne.step3: This button will take you to the PDF of your recipe.
cardOne.step4: This button will trigger a popup to save your recipe if you are logged in.
cardOne.step5: This button will allow you to reset your recipe and start fresh.
cardOne.step6: This section allows you to select the measurement units for weight and volume. You can switch between metric and US units in your account settings.
cardOne.step7: This form is for getting an initial must with your desired Original Gravity and volume. Using this form after you have entered other ingredients WILL CLEAR out all ingredients beyond one honey row and one water row.
cardOne.step8: Here is the ingredient row. Search for any ingredient in the MeadTools database. If you don't find the one you need, you can add your own! Just input the name of the ingredient and fill in the brix (percent sugar) and you're good to go!
cardOne.step9: Flip this switch for any ingredients that have sugar and won't be fermented on. If you're adding fruit to secondary, or backsweetening with honey, this switch is what you want.

cardSeven.step1: Finally we have the recipe PDF. View everything about your recipe in one place here.
cardSeven.step2: This button will pull up a dialog to print your recipe. Navigate the options to save as a pdf.
cardSeven.step3: Don't forget to save your recipe to your account so you can come back to it later.

cardSix.step1: This page allows you to enter notes that will be visible on your recipe PDF on the next page. You can have up to 10 notes of each kind.

cardThree.step1: Here are your nutrient calculator results.
cardThree.step2: Click one of the switches to toggle one of the available nutrients or toggle other to use something else. You just need to know the amount of YAN the nutrient provides.
cardThree.step3: Schedules are automatically calculated, but if you are still coming up short on your YAN, you can adjust amounts here.
cardThree.step4: Adjust the number of staggered additions you plan on using here.
cardThree.step5: This section shows the total amount of nutrients you need to use as well as the amount per each addition.
cardThree.step6: This warning is visible if your total required YAN is not met by the current nutrients. If this is visible, click the gear icon next to one of the selected nutrients and adjust the Max g/L field.
cardThree.step7: The last section on this page shows your go-ferm details. This tells you the amount of go-ferm and water required. This section is not visible if you selected "No go-ferm" on the previous page.

cardTwo.step2: Here you'll find all the inputs for the nutrient calculator. These inputs are disabled as part of the recipe builder because they are set on the first page.
cardTwo.step3: This is the only editable input in this section. The offset is calculated by default based on the amount of fruit in your recipe. If you want to adjust, you can here.
cardTwo.step4: Here you can adjust all of your yeast details. Select a brand from the list and you will get a list of yeasts from that brand. If you're using a yeast not on the list, just pick 'Other' and you can type in the name of your yeast. Just be sure to also set your nitrogen requirement to match.
cardTwo.step5: Here you can select the type of go-ferm you plan to use (or none) and adjust the yeast amount if the automatically calculated amount doesn't work for you.
